summary.p: 1 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: E 16264 E; Qurʾānic Text: Q 3:148-3:151; 7 lines per page; Dimensions: 152 x 95mm; Estimated date of production: 700-900 (?).
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts kept by the University Museums in Philaldelphia, written by Giorgio Levi Della Vida gives the following information (Levi Della Vida 1981, p. 158):

"125. Inv. E. 16264 E. 3rd century A.H./9th century A. D. Yellowish-brown parchment (the brown shade is probably due to the action of moisture). 9.5 x 15.2 cm. Written on both faces, seven broken lines to the page. This small piece is broken on all sides; however, it covers almost the whole size of the original sheet: only the margins and a few letters at the beginning and the end of each line have been destroyed. From the Ellen W. Harrison Collection. Recto: Kor. 3,148 (141); [وحسـ]ـن – 149 (142) تطيعوا الذ[ين]. Verso: 3,149 (142) [كـ]ـفرو – 151 (144) كفرو[ا]. The script, elaborated and expanded, with very narrow intervals between the lines, closely resembles that of the „Amajur“ Koran from Damascus (see B. Moritz, article „Arabic Writing“ in Encyclopaedia of Islam I 388 a, Plate IV.2) which is older than 256-260 A. H./869-874A.D. The bend towards the right of the lower end of the alifs is very pronounced; the final nūn is very little rounded. Prolongation alif is used in verse 150 (verso line 5) where the Cairo edition omits it. Diacritical signs are not used, except on verso line 3 for the bāʾ in فتنقلبوا (verse 149). Vowels are marked with red dots. seven-petaled gold rosette marks the end of verse 148 on recto line 3; a much larger one, decorated with blue points on its center and around the circumference, is put at the beginning of the line (verso line 5) where verse 150 ends."
